At 19:16 2005-12-13, you wrote:
>I am writing some unit test classes for a project I'm working on.  I
>use Apache Commons Logging as a wrapper for Log4J but I keep getting
>the following error messages when I run the tests:

Personally, I'd get Commons Logging out of the mix.  It has been a 
real pain in the neck on the last several projects I've worked 
on.  The first was my fault - seemed like a good idea at the 
time.  Getting it to find the correct configuration, use it and not 
get stomped on by someone else's library's decision to use Log4J was 
not possible on that particular project.  The following projects each 
had problems with trying to get Commons Logging to find the correct 
configuration.

If you are developing a library that might get mixed in with someone 
else's decision on a logging implementation, well, then Commons 
Logging might be worth the climb.

If you're developing for your own application, where you or your 
organization decide what logging package to use, ditch commons 
logging and use the direct logger.

Take a look at the Log4J pages

http://logging.apache.org/log4j/docs/documentation.html

especially the links to

http://www.qos.ch/logging/thinkAgain.jsp
http://radio.weblogs.com/0122027/2003/08/15.html
